notes.note: Keyboard shortcuts have now been added for editing and deleting a selected credential on `about:logins`. For editing - `Alt + enter` (`Option + return` on macOS) and for deleting - `Alt + Backspace` (`Option + Delete` on macOS).
Users on Ubuntu Linux now have the ability to import from Chromium when both are installed as Snap packages.
Users can now use an added devtools feature to simulate browser tabs to be offline.
Picture-in-Picture now supports corner snapping on Windows and Linux - just hold `Ctrl` as you move the PiP window.

By default, Firefox now uses TLS trust anchors (e.g., certificates) added to the operating system by the user or an administrator. This works on Windows, macOS, and Android, and it can be turned off in the "Privacy & Security" section of Firefox settings, under "Certificates".

Firefox now supports a setting (in Preferences → Privacy & Security) to enable [Global Privacy Control][1]. With this opt-in feature, Firefox informs the websites that the user doesn’t want their data to be shared or sold.

![UI setting for GPC][2]


  [1]: https://globalprivacycontrol.org/
  [2]: https://www.mozilla.org/media/img/firefox/releasenotes/note-images/120_relnote_GCP.png

Firefox supports a new “Copy Link Without Site Tracking” feature in the context menu which ensures that copied links no longer contain tracking information.

![copy site image][1]


  [1]: https://www.mozilla.org/media/img/firefox/releasenotes/note-images/120_relnote_copylink.png

Firefox has enabled Cookie Banner Blocker by default in private windows for all users in Germany. Firefox will now auto-refuse cookies and dismiss annoying cookie banners for supported sites. We are looking to expand support for this soon.

Firefox has enabled URL Tracking Protection by default in private windows for all Firefox users in Germany. Firefox will remove non-essential URL query parameters that are often used to track users across the web, thereby continuing to protect our users’ online privacy.

`lh` and `rlh` units can now be parsed and computed correctly as [lengths][1]. This allows authors to specify lengths in terms of the element's (or the root element's) line height.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/length

[WebAssembly GC][1] is now enabled by default, which allows new languages, such as [Dart][2] or [Kotlin][3], to run on Firefox. This makes it possible for reference cycles between the guest language and host browser to be collected. 


  [1]: https://github.com/WebAssembly/gc/blob/main/proposals/gc/Overview.md
  [2]: https://wasmio.tech/sessions/flutter-dart-and-wasm-gc-a-new-model-for-web-applications/
  [3]: https://kotlinlang.org/docs/wasm-overview.html#browser-support

The [User Activation API][1] has now been added, allowing JavaScript to check if the user currently is or has been active with the page (clicking, etc) with `navigator.userActivation`.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UserActivation

Early Hints Preconnect, the informational [status code 103][1], is now enabled. This allows servers to send resource Link headers before the final HTTP response and improves performance on servers using this feature. ([read more)][2]


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/103
  [2]: https://blog.cloudflare.com/early-hints/

text:
Firefox Beta gets updated 3 times a week and as a consequence, the release notes for the Beta channel are updated continuously to reflect features that have reached sufficient maturity to benefit from community feedback and bug reports.


**Warning: Features listed here may or may *not* make a final release of Firefox.**

In addition to these release notes, you can follow ongoing development via our [@FirefoxBeta][1] Twitter account.


  [1]: https://twitter.com/firefoxbeta
title: Firefox 120.0beta Beta
